Name: Ethametsulfuron-methyl
Description: Ethametsulfuron-methyl is a methyl ester resulting from the formal condensation of the carboxy group of ethametsulfuron with methanol. A herbicide used for the control of broad-leaved weeds in oil seed rape and fodder rape. It has a role as a herbicide and an EC 2.2.1.6 (acetolactate synthase) inhibitor. It is a diamino-1,3,5-triazine, a N-sulfonylurea, an aromatic ether, a benzoate ester and a methyl ester. It is functionally related to an ethametsulfuron.

plant_translocations.content: The metabolism and fate of ethametsulfuron-methyl in rutabaga were studied. Absorption and translocation of [14C]ethametsulfuron-methyl in rutabaga remained stable over 50 days, with less than 4% of recovered radioactivity in the root. Ethametsulfuron-methyl was metabolized into two major metabolites, O-desethylethametsulfuron-methyl and N-desmethyl-O-desethylethametsulfuron-methyl, after an unstable R-hydroxy ethoxy intermediate dissipated 3 days after treatment. Residue analysis indicated that at a spray dose of 30 g of active ingredient ha-1 and a harvest weight of 0.5 kg, the edible portion of rutabaga root would contain no ethametsulfuron-methyl and 1.3 ppb total of both identified metabolites. Toxicological assessment suggests that ethametsulfuron-methyl and its metabolites pose little or no risk to consumers of rutabagas.
plant_translocations.reference: Van Eerd, L. L., & Hall, J. C. (2000). Metabolism and fate of [14C] ethametsulfuron-methyl in rutabaga (Brassica napobrassica Mill.). Journal of agricultural and food chemistry, 48(7), 2977-2985.

method.Test Plant: Rutabaga (Brassica napus var. napobrassica cv. Laurentian)
method.Apply Location: Foliar application on adaxial midsection of the third leaf
method.Plant Growth Condition: Seeds planted in Styrofoam cups with Turface montmorillonite clay potting medium for absorption/translocation/metabolism experiments. For other experiments, plants grown in Premier Promix peat moss potting medium. Grown in controlled environment room at 24/16°C day/night, 16h photoperiod, 450 μmol/m2/s light intensity, 65% relative humidity. Fertilized 3-4 times weekly with 20-20-20 NPK solution.
method.Chemical Preparation: Triazine-U-14C and phenyl-U-14C labeled ethametsulfuron-methyl (specific activities 752.1 and 605.1 MBq/mmol respectively, >94% purity) dissolved in 0.1M phosphate buffered saline pH 7.5 with 10% ethanol and 0.5% Tween 20.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Ten 1-μL drops of 5.1 kBq (~300,000 DPM, 30 g ai/ha/plant) 14C-ethametsulfuron solution applied to adaxial midsection of third leaf at 3-leaf stage.
method.Other Information: Plants harvested at 3, 10, 15, 30, 50 days after treatment (DAT). Absorption determined by leaf rinse method. Translocation assessed by combustion of plant parts

plant_translocations.content: Under controlled-environment conditions, ethametsulfuron-methyl doses that inhibited growth by 50% (ED50) were >100 and <1 g of active ingredient (ai) ha-1 for ethametsulfuron-methyl-resistant (R) and -susceptible (S) wild mustard, respectively. Absorption and translocation of the herbicide showed no differences between the two biotypes. Three days after treatment, approximately 90%, 5%, and 2% of the applied [14C]ethametsulfuron-methyl was found in the treated leaf, foliage, and roots of each biotype, respectively. Acetolactate synthase extracted from both biotypes was equally sensitive to both ethametsulfuron-methyl and chlorsulfuron, indicating that resistance was not due to differences in the target site, absorption, or translocation. However, ethametsulfuron-methyl was metabolized more rapidly in the R than the S biotype, with 82%, 73%, 42%, 30%, and 17% of the recovered radioactivity remaining as ethametsulfuron-methyl in R wild mustard 3, 6, 18, 48, and 72 h after treatment, respectively. Conversely, 84%, 79%, 85%, and 73% of the 14C was ethametsulfuron-methyl in the S biotype 12, 24, 48, and 72 h after treatment, respectively. Based on these results, resistance is proposed to be due to enhanced metabolism of ethametsulfuron-methyl in the R biotype.
plant_translocations.reference: Veldhuis, L. J., Hall, L. M., O'Donovan, J. T., Dyer, W., & Hall, J. C. (2000). Metabolism-based resistance of a wild mustard (Sinapis arvensis L.) biotype to ethametsulfuron-methyl. Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, 48(7), 2986-2990.

method.Test Plant: Resistant (R) and susceptible (S) biotypes of wild mustard (Sinapis arvensis)
method.Apply Location: Foliar application on adaxial surface of second fully expanded leaf
method.Plant Growth Condition: Seeds germinated on 0.6% agar then transplanted to 10-cm pots with soil. Grown in controlled environment room at 25/21°C day/night, 16h photoperiod, 500 μmol/m2/s light intensity. Fertilized twice weekly with 20-20-20 NPK nutrient solution.
method.Chemical Preparation: [phenyl-U-14C]ethametsulfuron-methyl (specific activity 605.9 MBq/mmol) dissolved in ethanol, then diluted in 0.1M phosphate buffer pH 7.5 with 0.5% Tween 20 to final 563 μM concentration and 10% ethanol.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Ten 1-μL drops of radiolabeled 563 μM ethametsulfuron solution applied to adaxial leaf surface of R and S plants at 3-4 leaf stage.
method.Other Information: Plants harvested at 0, 12, 24, 48, 72 hours after treatment. Unabsorbed 14C washed from treated leaf.
